b'Our talented crew members focus on improving their communities year-round, not just on #GivingTuesday. Jennie H., a research economist, shares, \xe2\x80\x9cI #MakeItHappen for my community by leveraging my background in academic research on early childhood education to support our giving campaign and Strong Start for Kids program, which focuses on improving kindergarten readiness. This year I used that knowledge to provide research based insights and ideas to encourage participation, especially under the unique circumstances. Together, we were able to raise millions for the community.\xe2\x80\x9d Link in bio to learn more about our community stewardship.'

b"Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s VetsConnect resource group seeks to drive Vanguard's mission by building a community of veterans, families, and friends. Member Bill F. shares, \xe2\x80\x9cAs a part of VetsConnect here at Vanguard, I #MakeItHappen as the liaison to American Corporate Partners, a nonprofit aimed at pairing corporate leaders with veterans and spouses transitioning to the private sector. Before lockdown, I traveled to Washington, D.C., along with representatives from 45 other businesses, to discuss the unique employment challenges that military spouses face. They face a myriad of unique challenges, including a lack of license and certification transferability across state lines and fragmented resumes due to constant relocation and deployments. The chance to address these questions is an extremely rewarding experience. For me, it represents an evolution of my desire to serve, aided by the mission and crew of Vanguard, where we serve families who have served for us.\xe2\x80\x9d"

b'We\xe2\x80\x99re not surprised about this week\xe2\x80\x99s promising COVID-19 vaccine news. The fields of genetics and biomedicine have been rife with the spread of innovative ideas. It\xe2\x80\x99s a phenomenon we identified in The Idea Multiplier, our 2019 research that found that future productivity is fundamentally driven by the generation, dissemination, and further expansion of ideas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x94 Joe Davis, Vanguard global chief economist, comments on the news that a vaccine candidate appears to protect a vast majority from COVID-19. b'Today marks the conclusion of Hispanic Heritage Month. Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s employee resource group HOLA (Hispanic/Latinx Organization for Leadership and Advancement) celebrated with a variety of activities for crew. Amanda G. shares, \xe2\x80\x9cEvery year I am incredibly proud of the work Vanguard does to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month both internally for our crew and externally for our clients and local communities. This year, Vanguard went above and beyond to #MakeItHappen to celebrate in our virtual environment, creating connectivity during a time of distance. From cooking classes to trivia, HOLA has delivered fun and informative events that highlight the traditions and cultures of the Hispanic and Latino community. Through these efforts, Vanguard continues to build a stronger sense of inclusion for community members and allies alike.\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Q: What\xe2\x80\x99s Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s outlook for market returns?

A: In short, stock market prospects have improved since the market correction, while expected returns from bonds remain subdued. We would advise, as always, that investors maintain diversified portfolios appropriate to their goals, and to invest for the long term. Attempting to time the market during extreme market volatility is tempting but rarely profitable. \xe2\x80\x93Joe Davis, Vanguard Global Chief Economist

For Joe\xe2\x80\x99s full answer, read more using the link in bio.'
b'Financial advice can help bring your goals into focus. Link in bio.'

b'Q: At the end of last year, Vanguard was expecting inflation to remain soft. Has your forecast changed in light of the pandemic?\n\nA: Not significantly. Many commentators have talked up the prospect of a resurgence in inflation in 2021, particularly as the debt-to-GDP ratios of developed economies have increased dramatically because of spending to mitigate the effects of the pandemic. We think it\xe2\x80\x99s more likely that inflation overall will be held in check by demand lagging a rebound in supply in all the major economies, especially in face-to-face sectors that we believe will experience a high degree of consumer reluctance until there is a vaccine. That, in turn, could set the stage for central banks to maintain easy terms for accessing money well into 2021. \xe2\x80\x93Joe Davis, Vanguard Global Chief Economist'

b'Joe Davis, Vanguard Global Chief Economist, sat down with our global economists to take stock of how the pandemic has reshaped Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s outlook for the economy and where we see markets going from here. Link in bio.'

b'Q: What does the prospect of only gradual economic growth mean for employment?\n\nA: A lot depends on the fate of furloughed workers. Official measures of unemployment across the globe have risen by historically unprecedented amounts in a short time. And unfortunately, in many countries the true unemployment picture is even worse once furloughed workers are considered\xe2\x80\x94those who are not working but are being paid by governments or employers. There\xe2\x80\x99s a chance that furloughed workers could move straight back into work as lockdowns end, which would make this type of unemployment not so costly. But there\xe2\x80\x99s a risk that high unemployment will persist, especially considering those who have already lost jobs permanently and the furloughed workers who may not easily move back into work. -Peter Westaway, Vanguard chief economist for Europe'
b'Start saving for your next trip*\n\n*However far away it may be :grinning_face_with_big_eyes:'

b'Q: With many countries having just gone through extraordinarily quick and sharp declines in GDP, there\xe2\x80\x99s been a lot of speculation about what shape the recovery will take. What\xe2\x80\x99s Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s view for Latin America?\n\nA: Latin America faces an especially challenging period. Brazil, Latin America\xe2\x80\x99s largest economy, has had a particularly hard time containing the virus. The World Health Organization (WHO) puts the number of confirmed cases in that country second only to the number in the United States. Peru, Chile, and Mexico also are among the 10 countries with the highest number of confirmed cases, according to the WHO. The International Monetary Fund in June downgraded its economic outlook for Latin America to a full-year contraction of 9.4%, having projected a contraction of 5.2% for the period just 3 months earlier. \xe2\x80\x93Roger Aliaga-D\xc3\xadaz, Vanguard Chief Economist for the Americas'
b'Live for today. Plan for tomorrow. Learn more about saving for college. Link in bio.'

b'Q: With many countries having just gone through extraordinarily quick and sharp declines in GDP, there\xe2\x80\x99s been a lot of speculation about what shape the recovery will take. What\xe2\x80\x99s Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s view for China?\n\nA: We expect the recovery to be faster and more V-shaped in China [than in developed economies], for a couple of reasons. China has so far managed to contain the virus relatively quickly, and its economy has a larger share of manufacturing and construction activities, which rely less on face-to-face interaction and benefit from the government boost to infrastructure investment. In fact, we\xe2\x80\x99re seeing many industries in China not only recovering but clawing back lost output not produced during the lockdown, so we expect its economy to return more quickly to previrus levels. \xe2\x80\x93Qian Wang, Vanguard chief economist for Asia-Pacific'
b'Vanguard Global Chief Economist Joe Davis provides an economic update amid the pandemic. Learn more\xe2\x80\x94link in bio.'

b'Q: With many countries having just gone through extraordinarily quick and sharp declines in GDP, there\xe2\x80\x99s been a lot of speculation about what shape the recovery will take. What\xe2\x80\x99s Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s view?\n\nA: Indeed, the hit to economic activity has been severe. We estimate the overall peak-to-trough global GDP contraction was around 9% in the first half of 2020. Comparable collapses in economic activity are hard to find outside wartime: Global GDP fell 6% peak to trough during the global financial crisis, for example, and by 1.8% during the 1973 oil crisis. So what will the recovery look like? Will it be V-shaped or U-shaped? Probably a little of both. We anticipate a first phase characterized by a rapid recovery in the supply side of the economy as businesses reopen and restrictions are eased. We expect that to be followed by a second, more protracted phase in which demand, especially in sensitive face-to-face sectors, only gradually returns. Overall the trajectory of the recovery is likely to be an elongated U-shape, with GDP growth not returning to normal until well into 2021 and quite possibly beyond in major economies. The one exception is China. Our baseline assessment is that a vaccine won\xe2\x80\x99t be widely available before the end of 2021; a vaccine sooner than that would make us more optimistic about the prospects for recovery. But we unfortunately see risks around our forecast skewed to the downside, strongly linked to health outcomes and the potential for instances of the virus to necessitate renewed widespread shutdowns. \xe2\x80\x93Peter Westaway, Vanguard chief economist for Europe'
b'Should paying off debt be your primary financial goal? We share why you may want to focus on something else first\xe2\x80\x94link in bio.'

b'Q: The title of Vanguard\xe2\x80\x99s outlook for 2020, published last year, was \xe2\x80\x9cThe New Age of Uncertainty.\xe2\x80\x9d It seems almost prophetic in retrospect, right?\n\nA: It\xe2\x80\x99s true that we were expecting heightened uncertainty this year owing to concerns about global growth, unpredictable policymaking, trade tensions, and Brexit negotiations. But we couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have foreseen a viral pandemic that would be so devastating in terms of human cost, curtailed economic activity, and disrupted financial markets. It\xe2\x80\x99s really an unprecedented event that defies conventional labels. We\xe2\x80\x99ve been broadly supportive of the extraordinarily rapid and robust monetary and fiscal responses from governments worldwide to blunt the damage. Many central banks have embraced a \xe2\x80\x9cwhatever it takes\xe2\x80\x9d approach, which has included slashing interest rates and providing liquidity to financial markets ... That notwithstanding, while this may be the deepest and shortest recession in modern economic history, I want to stress that we see a long road back to a pre-virus economy. \xe2\x80\x93Joe Davis, Vanguard global chief economist'
b'Every great investment plan should leave room for a little bit of magic.'

b'Vanguard economists analyzed the impact of pandemic containment measures across various industries, finding that sectors that rely heavily on face-to-face interaction\xe2\x80\x94such as retail trade, hospitality, and transportation\xe2\x80\x94experienced a large shock to activity. The recent Vanguard Economic and Market Outlook report digs in deeper to sector impact: link in bio.'

b"Crystal Hardie Langston, Vanguard Chief Diversity Officer, sent a recent message to our crew sharing her personal feelings, and, importantly, reinforcing our values and the crew\xe2\x80\x99s role in creating an inclusive environment at Vanguard. \xe2\x80\x9cWhile external to Vanguard, these events have a real impact on crew that belong to these communities and the allies who support them. I am devastated at the loss of more lives due to prejudice and bigotry, anxious about the possibility this could happen to me or any of my loved ones, and infuriated about the weight of stress and fear that so many have to live with daily. We all likely have peers, team members, leaders, and business partners who are sad, angry, fearful, traumatized\xe2\x80\x94or all of the above\xe2\x80\x94as these themes affect their communities broadly, their loved ones directly, and in some cases themselves. In these moments, it's important that we create safe environments in which crew can share their thoughts and leaders can lean in to listen. What happens in the external world does not get left outside when crew come to work. Our authentic selves cannot be separated from us during the workday if we all want to be our best and deliver our best. Safe spaces for sharing enable growth, learning, and the opportunity for crew and their perspectives and experiences to feel valued and included. At Vanguard, we stand for inclusion, cultivating difference, and equity. We all have a role in creating an inclusive environment where all crew feel connected, appreciated, and heard. 
Here are some points to keep in mind: 
1. Ask. Check in on your co-workers and ask how they are doing. 
2. Listen with the intent to understand and not to reply. Listening can often be the best support you can offer. 
3. Accept that you may be starting from a place of vulnerability. You may not know much about the situation at hand or have all the right words, but be willing to learn and understand the experience of your fellow crew member. You don't have to be an expert or know all the answers to empathize and demonstrate your interest in others' experiences.\xe2\x80\x9d #InclusionAtVanguard"

b'Greg Davis, Vanguard Chief Investment Officer, shares his story: As a Black man growing up in the United States, you learn certain things very early on. I was a still a boy when I learned that people looked at me differently and treated me differently. As I grew older, I learned that it didn\xe2\x80\x99t matter how hard I worked or how friendly I was, I was still an object of fear or hate for some, and for no other reason than the color of my skin. While I have been fortunate to achieve a level of professional success, the truth is that if I\xe2\x80\x99m running, biking, or walking down the street, the first thing people see is a Black man. For many folks, that comes with painful assumptions.

At this stage in my life, my kids are top of mind. I\xe2\x80\x99m the father of two Black teenagers: a 16-year-old son and 14-year-old-daughter. My son just got his learner\xe2\x80\x99s permit. Like all parents, I am worried about him being behind the wheel on his own. But not all parents also have the terror of wondering how he will be treated by those who don\xe2\x80\x99t see him for the sweet, intelligent, responsible child that he is, but instead see a crime waiting to happen. I watch in horror how people of color are mistreated in a variety of settings: law enforcement, the judicial system, the media and in their day to day lives.

Floyd. Arbery. Taylor. The list goes on and on \xe2\x80\x94and those are just the names that make the news. Ask yourself: how did you feel when you saw Colin Kaepernick kneel during the national anthem? Were you upset? Do you now better understand the non-violent protest he started? Do you feel differently about how we as a society treated him and his actions? He was speaking to a wound that is unhealed in this country. It\xe2\x80\x99s a wound that activists have been shedding light on for years, without much progress. I don\xe2\x80\x99t condone the violence and loss of property we are seeing, but I also remember the words of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.: \xe2\x80\x9cA riot is the language of the unheard.\xe2\x80\x9d I hope we are listening and are ready to do the work to make this country that we love what it is capable of being.

#InclusionAtVanguard'

b'You may be hearing about a "V-shaped" or "U-shaped" economic recovery, but what does that mean? A V-shaped recovery, named after the letter it resembles, is defined by a sharp economic decline followed by a speedy and sustained recovery. A U-shaped recovery, which also represents the letter it depicts, happens when a recession occurs and the economy does not immediately bounce back, it but may last 12\xe2\x80\x9324 months before bouncing back to its previous peak. Learn more about how Vanguard believes we may experience a combination of both\xe2\x80\x94link in bio.'

b'Principles for Investing Success: Part 4. Investing can provoke strong emotions. During times of market uncertainty, you may find yourself tempted to make impulsive decisions, or you may experience "paralysis by analysis," unable to decide on how best to implement an effective investment strategy or when to rebalance your portfolio. Discipline and perspective can help you remain committed to a long-term investment philosophy through periods of market uncertainty.'

b"Principles for Investing Success: Part 3. Markets are unpredictable. Costs are forever. The lower your costs, the greater your share of an investment's return. And research suggests lower-cost investments outperform higher-cost alternatives. You can't control the markets, but you can control your costs and tax liability. #FinancialLiteracy"

b'Principles for Investing Success: Part 2. Create a sound investment strategy by choosing an asset allocation in line with your financial objectives. Build your allocation based on reasonable expectations and diversify your portfolio to avoid exposure to unnecessary risks. Balance is the key. #FinancialLiteracy'

b'Principles for Investing Success: Part 1. Create appropriate investment goals you can measure and attain. Defining your goals clearly and planning realistic ways to achieve them can help protect you from common mistakes that could derail your progress. #FinancialLiteracy'

b'Market volatility: by the numbers.'

b"Earlier this morning, the markets were halted for 15 minutes. What does this mean and why does it happen? These halts, called \xe2\x80\x9ccircuit breakers,\xe2\x80\x9d represent the thresholds at which trading is halted market-wide for single-day declines in the S&P 500 Index. Circuit breakers halt trading on the nation's stock markets during dramatic drops and are set at 7%, 13%, and 20% of the closing price for the previous day. This morning we entered a Level 1 circuit breaker because the market dropped to 7% below yesterday's S&P 500 Index closing price.

What are the different levels and how long do they last?
Level 1 halt (7%): Trading will halt for 15 minutes if the drop occurs before 3:25 p.m. At or after 3:25 p.m trading shall continue, unless there is a Level 3 halt.

Level 2 halt (13%): Trading will halt for 15 minutes if the drop occurs before 3:25 p.m. At or after 3:25 p.m. trading shall continue, unless there is a Level 3 halt.

Level 3 halt (20%): Trading will halt for the remainder of the trading day if this occurs at any time during the trading day."
